items.title: The ‘internet of beings’ is the next fronteir that could change humanity and healthcare
items.summary:
- The 'internet of beings' would extend digital connectivity into human organs, creating a third internet phase focused on continuous health monitoring and prevention.
- Biorobots or gel-based sensors could actively heal by releasing medications or activating vaccines when needed.
- Gene editing and molecular microsurgery might repair DNA, but raise ethical and security concerns, including immortality fantasies and hacked bodies.

items.title: The banality of Jeffery Epstein’s expanding online world
items.summary:
- Jmail.world publicly reconstructs Epstein’s online life by merging released emails and docs into a Gmail-like inbox plus JPhotos, JDrive, JFlights, Jemini, and Jotify.
- It uses public material and redacted docs to reveal emails, discussions, redacted images, and mundane items like market updates and articles.
- The piece frames the project as a troubling analogue to investigators hoovering data—fascinating yet horrifying, a data-driven portrait that remains artificial and curated.

items.title: Why high-speed rail may not work the best in the U.S.
items.summary:
- Global HSR is widespread (Japan, China, Europe); the US remains largely absent, with challenges cited by Mattingly.
- Mattingly distinguishes conventional (<80 mph), higher-speed (90–125 mph), and true high-speed (≥150 mph) with dedicated infrastructure.
- The piece frames ongoing debates on feasibility, funding, and planning for US services that may or may not meet high-speed criteria.

items.title: From OpenAI to Nvidia, here’s a list of recent multibillion-dollar AI deals
items.summary:
- Nvidia signed its largest deal by licensing Groq tech for AI chips, signaling stronger competitiveness amid surging demand.
- Amazon reportedly eyeing about $10B investment in OpenAI.
- Disney plans around $1B investment in OpenAI and a three-year licensing deal covering Sora and ChatGPT Images for Disney IP, excluding talent likenesses or voices.

items.title: ‘Meme depression,’ Ghibli-gate, 6-7: An internet-culture roundup for 2025
items.summary:
- 2025 fuses meme chaos with real-world anecdotes, fueling debates over policy, platforms, and online conduct.
- Notable threads include an anticipated TikTok ban that never happened, RedNote as an alternative, and viral cases like the American woman in Pakistan.
- Odd moments, from the deep-sea anglerfish near Tenerife to the Cybertruck backlash, shaped online sentiment and brand narratives.

items.title: Why Apple and Google want your ID
items.summary:
- Apple Wallet/Google Wallet now digitize IDs, including passports, usable at TSA checkpoints (250+ locations).
- Setup: scan front/back IDs, upload a photo, record brief facial movements for verification, then the digital ID appears in the wallet next to Apple Pay/Google Pay.
- Passport IDs are nationwide; digitized driver’s licenses/state IDs vary by state; listed states include AZ, AR, CA, CO, GA, IA, MD, MT, NM, ND, PR; Apple/Google also work in HI and OH; some states have their own apps.

items.title: 5 surprising ways to use AI
items.summary:
- Profiles Alexandra Samuel, who built 200+ automation scripts and an idea database to draft pitches.
- Uses Suno to generate songs that explain complex concepts, adding a musical thread to AI education.
- Hosts the Me + Viv podcast, exploring a trained AI assistant as coach and collaborator, with skeptical guests.

items.title: Tesla’s Model 3 emergency door release controls are being investigated
items.summary:
- The NHTSA opened a defect probe into 179,071 2022 Tesla Model 3 sedans over concerns that emergency door release controls may be hard to access or clearly identifiable in an emergency.
- The probe follows a defect petition alleging the mechanical door release is hidden, unlabeled, and not intuitive to locate during emergencies.
- The case sits amid broader questions about electronic door latches vs. mechanical releases and comes after a lawsuit alleging a Model S trap during a fiery crash.

items.title: France’s postal service was hit by a major cyberattack right before Christmas. Here are the hackers who did it
items.summary:
- A pro-Russian hacking group, Noname057, claimed responsibility for a major cyberattack that knocked La Poste’s central systems offline, halting package deliveries and disrupting online payments. 
- Paris prosecutors say the DGSI has taken over the investigation as outages persisted and package tracking and payments were disrupted. 
- The outage, caused by a DDoS attack, underscores hybrid warfare concerns in Europe and adds to a broader pattern of European cyber incidents.

items.title: Why TikTok’s ‘For You’ page is so valuable and what’s to change for U.S. users
items.summary:
- A U.S.-only TikTok would emerge from a majority stake sale to U.S. investors, with approvals aimed by Jan 22, 2026.
- The core For You algorithm may be licensed, not transferred, keeping Chinese IP while the U.S. version uses the tech—raising control questions.
- Governance and licensing terms are still being hammered out as China blocks direct export of the algo.

items.title: Altman: Once upon a time, Google could have dominated OpenAI
items.summary:
- OpenAI and Google are positioned as top contenders in an AI advertising era, with Altman hinting at ads inside ChatGPT to monetize free users.
- Ads could fund a $115B infrastructure push by 2029 and may roll out as early as 2026.
- The debate probes whether AI-native search and ads can reinvent monetization, given Google's data edge and OpenAI's web-reinvention stance.

items.title: How the Nex Playground game system became the holiday’s hottest toy
items.summary:
- Nex Playground is a 3-inch AI-powered cube that detects movement for controller-free, family-friendly play.
- It's outsized sales growth: 5k (2023), 150k (2024), projected 600k (2025), aiming to carve a Wii-like mass market.
- It focuses on simple, communal play, excludes shooters/mature titles, and has a loyal fan base yet puzzling surge.

items.title: Google is betting on carbon capture tech to lower data center emissions. Here’s how it works
items.summary: - Google signed a corporate power purchase agreement to back a natural-gas plant in Illinois designed for carbon capture and storage (CCS), aiming to power data centers with lower emissions.\n- CCS captures CO2 from power plants or processes, transports it (often via pipelines), and injects it underground for permanent storage.\n- The article frames CCS as a possible path to decarbonize gas-fired generation powering data centers, a view from an engineer who wrote a 2024 book on carbon storage.

items.title: Should you track your family’s location?
Why Waymo went down in San Francisco
items.summary:
- Over the SF weekend, a power outage disabled traffic signals, grounding several Waymo robotaxi and causing congestion as vehicles ran with hazard lights.
- Remote assistance was hampered by overloaded networks; Waymo paused service per city guidance; service resumed after power restoration, with lessons for resilience and region-specific prep.
- Waymo cites prior responses to emergencies and says it will use the weekend's experience to strengthen emergency protocols and resilience before expanding in new cities.

items.title: Consuming news from AI shifts our opinions and reality. Here’s how
items.summary:
- AI-written headlines and summaries shape what people see by emphasizing certain facts and framing others.
- Persona-based steerability means the same facts can be presented with different tones depending on who prompts the model.
- As AI becomes a gatekeeper of news, trust, bias, and political discourse may shift across society.

items.title: FCC bans new foreign-made drones over national security concerns
items.summary:
- The FCC bans new foreign-made drones in the U.S., blocking new Chinese-made drones (DJI, Autel) for national security reasons.
- Drones and critical components produced abroad were deemed to pose unacceptable risks; exemptions possible if the Pentagon or DHS find no risk; review deadline Dec. 23.
- The move targets upcoming events (World Cup 2026, America250, 2028 Olympics); AUVSI calls for domestic production and secured supply chains amid China’s material restrictions.

items.title: This AI startup is extending an olive branch between humans and machines
items.summary:
- Olive.is is a student-founded AI startup that emerged in fall 2024, led by five Georgia Tech undergrads and CEO Bill Nguyen, aiming to advance voice AI.
- It focuses on improving AI's interpretation of spoken language by accounting for inflection and dialect, to enrich education and other sectors.
- The company has raised $5 million in seed funding from Owl Ventures and Georgia Tech and is still researching its model.

items.title: How a former Forest Service employee changed the future of housing in California
items.summary:
- Brian Hanlon, a former Forest Service employee, helped shape California's 2025 housing reforms aimed at near-transit development.
- At Terroir with Silicon Valley leaders, the plan argues policy barriers—not landlords—block housing more than anything else.
- Early activism featured clashes with tenant advocates and a screening incident that led to Hanlon being forced to leave.

items.title: The Trump administration is trying to kill these offshore wind projects over ‘national security’ concerns that experts say are bogus
items.summary:
- The Interior Department suspended five offshore wind leases under construction, citing national security concerns, affecting projects in New York, Massachusetts, Virginia, and Rhode Island.
- Critics say the rationale is politically motivated and that radar interference from turbines is well understood and solvable via software patches or radar upgrades.
- The piece notes potential political deals (like a natural gas pipeline) and argues offshore wind could aid military communications, while China already runs many offshore wind farms.

items.title: How ‘Cyberchase’ keeps up
items.summary: - Cyberchase centers on Motherboard and Hacker in a metaverse-like world, with Inez, Mattie, Jackie and Digit solving math challenges.\n- The publicly funded PBS Kids series, airing since 2002, teaches math concepts (subtraction, fractions, negatives) and updates content for social media and online games.\n- For spring 2026, it launches seven-minute episodes bridging full stories and short-form content, adapting to streaming platforms such as TikTok.

items.title: How will AI transform business in 2026?
items.summary:
- Relationship AI rises as a personal chief of staff; private-data moats and specialized LLM-based algorithms; governance of AI-led teams debated.
- End-to-end AI in work (healthcare included) creates hybrid human–AI teams; culture and performance reviews evolve; AI managers may emerge.
- Jobs outlook is mixed; AI-enabled roles rise as cross-functional, AI-fluent skills become valuable.

items.title: Detecting AI-written text is challenging, even for AI. Here’s why
Here’s how to protect your privacy when using AI assistants
items.summary:
- Do not share your innermost thoughts or sensitive data with AI assistants; keep conversations generic when possible.
- Quickly adjust privacy settings and disable data saving or chat history to reduce data collection.
- Stay aware of UI indicators and review related privacy tips to minimize exposure.

items.title: When AI-powered toys go rogue
items.summary:
- AI toys often rely on third-party models (e.g., GPT-4o) with limited manufacturer control, risking jailbroken or unsafe content.
- Kumma's case underscores transparency gaps about which models are used, how they’re trained, safeguards, and data practices.
- Experts urge caution—little evidence of benefits or long-term impact, with liability questions and regulatory gaps delaying safer adoption.

items.title: Alphabet buys data center energy specialist Intersect for $4.75 billion to help power AI
How U.S. tech built China’s surveillance state in Nepal
I correctly predicted ChatGPT. Here are my 6 AI predictions for 2026
What’s really going on with the TikTok deal
SoftBank is racing to close a $22.5 billion OpenAI funding gap before 2026
Business lessons of 2026, from Airbnb, Meta, LinkedIn, and more
items.summary: - Five Cs frame humanity’s apex: clear language for storytelling and organizing to scale via nation-states; rebuild these skills.\n- In high uncertainty, clear, brave decisions matter most; integrity and collective action help resist compromises.\n- Notes: Alexis McGill Johnson warns funding pressures push institutions to betray values; Chesky’s principle vs business decisions; leadership grounded in basics (e.g., children’s books as metaphors).

items.title: San Francisco’s power is mostly back after an outage that impacted 130,000 homes and businesses
items.summary:
- Power largely restored to about 113,000 of ~130,000 affected SF customers; ~17,000 remained without power as of noon.
- Cause linked to extensive damage from a fire at the 8th and Mission substation; restoration expected to be complex.
- PG&E mobilized more engineers; outage began Saturday after 1 p.m.; no injuries reported; transit disruptions and Waymo driverless rides affected.

items.title: School security industry may be booming, but little is helping to stop shootings
Inside HP’s AI bet to rebuild itself for the ‘work intelligence’ age
items.summary:
- HP is redefining itself as a work‑intelligence platform, unifying devices, software, services and cloud under a platform-led model to boost recurring revenue.
- AI PCs with on‑device neural processing units deliver faster, private inference and embed AI across print, docs, meetings and offline workflows.
- Hybrid compute, blending local AI with cloud scale, and DXP/lifecycle services signal a shift from device revenue to software and services.

items.title: Exploring a new city? Grab these 3 free, under-the-radar apps first
My Private, Free AI Setup
Apple’s 3 biggest wins and 3 greatest failures of 2025
items.summary:
- iPhone 17 lineup exceeded sales expectations, boosting Apple stock amid tariff fears as demand rose in the US and China, with upgrades to display, camera, and longer battery life.
- iPhone 17 Pro/Pro Max feature a new unibody design and up to 39 hours of battery life, strengthening premium positioning.
- Liquid Glass debuts as iOS 26’s design language, delivering a radical visual overhaul—the first major iOS redesign since 2013.

items.title: This brilliant free website makes Wikipedia infinitely better
items.summary:
- Wikiboard visualizes your Wikipedia browsing as a mind map, showing connections as you move between articles.
- It adds a cork-board style view of related topics you've encountered so you can jump into exploration immediately.
- The idea was shared as a tip in The Intelligence's free Cool Tools newsletter.

items.title: Meet Google Maps’s new intelligent planning companion
items.summary:
- Roadtrippers is described as a virtual companion that augments standard navigation (Google Maps, Waze, Apple Maps) with features to make road trips more entertaining and enjoyable.
- It's pitched for holiday travel planning or extended drives, offering on-route entertainment alongside your usual navigation.
- The tip originated in The Intelligence’s Cool Tools newsletter.

items.title: Sequoia’s Shaun Maguire accused an innocent Palestinian of being the Brown shooter. Then he doubled down
items.summary:
- Authorities identified Claudio Manuel Neves Valente as Brown University’s December 13 shooter and tied MIT professor Nuno Loureiro’s death to separate causes, countering online conspiracies promoted by Maguire.
- Maguire had publicly claimed a Palestinian Brown student was the shooter and speculated Loureiro’s death was tied to Jewish identity; Brown scrubbed the student’s online presence as a safety step.
- The piece notes Maguire’s history of inflammatory posts toward Muslims and pro-Palestine activists and mentions an open letter urging Sequoia to fire him; Sequoia did not comment.

items.title: YouTube creator’s finance livestream mysteriously appears on White House website
items.summary: - An unexpected livestream by YouTube creator Matt Farley (RealMattMoney) appeared for at least eight minutes on whitehouse.gov/live. - The White House said it is aware and investigating whether the incident was a hack or an inadvertent link. - Farley said he had no idea his stream would be publicly streamed by a government site, with the context tied to a longer personal-finance livestream.

items.title: Yes, the Trump administration is likely to buy more equity in more private companies in 2026
items.summary:
- The US government bought minority stakes in several private firms in 2025 and signals ongoing equity investments under Trump, framed as industrial policy.
- Advocates say it aligns the executive branch with vital industries, rebuilds supply chains, and reduces China exposure; critics warn of government venture-capital risks.
- The biggest stake is 9.9% in Intel, funded by $8.9B CHIPS Act money; debate continues on expanding equity to defense contractors and other crises-era precedents.

items.title: Instacart settles with FTC for $60 million over alleged false advertising
TikTok signs a deal forming a new U.S. unit including investors Oracle and Silver Lake
How AI made me more (and less) productive in 2025
Retro, a photo-sharing app for friends, lets you ‘time-travel’ through your camera roll
AI’s butterfly effect: The danger of cascade failures
Why brands are going unhinged on TikTok (and winning big)
Tin Can has reinvented the house phone for today’s families
Is ‘artificial general intelligence’ an illusion? Yann LeCun thinks so
items.summary:
- Yann LeCun argues AGI is a myth and humans aren’t true generalists; he favors focusing on narrow, reliable AI tasks.
- He criticizes the industry’s obsession with AGI and urges solving real-world problems to create value and reduce suffering.
- The debate weighs human vs machine limits in chess and math, questioning AGI as a practical target.
